metadata.titleEn: The mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) and permafrost thermal stability dataset over Tibetan Plateau for 2005-2015
metadata.description: Mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at a depth of zero annual amplitude and permafrost thermal stability type are fundamental importance for engineering planning and design, ecosystem management in permafrost region. This dataset is produced by integrating remotely sensed freezing degree-days and thawing degree-days, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, high-accuracy soil moisture data, and in situ MAGT measurements from 237 boreholes for the 2010s (2005-2015) on the Tibetan Plateau (TP) by using an ensemble learning method that employs a support vector regression (SVR) model based on distance-blocked resampling training data with 200 repetitions. Validation of the new permafrost map indicates that it is probably the most accurate of all available maps at present. The RMSE of MAGT is approximately 0.75 °C and the bias is approximately 0.01 °C. This map shows that the total area of permafrost on the TP is approximately 115.02 (105.47-129.59) *104 km2. The areas corresponding to the very stable, stable, semi-stable, transitional, and unstable types are 0.86*104 km2, 9.62*104 km2, 38.45*104 km2, 42.29*104 km2, and 23.80*104 km2, respectively. This new dataset is available for evaluate the permafrost change in the future on the TP as a baseline. More details can be found in Ran et al., (2020) that published at Science China Earth Sciences.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP), which is also called Earth's "Third Pole", is the highest and most extensive plateau in the world. The area of high-elevation permafrost on the TP ranks first in the world among middle- and low-latitude permafrost regions, and the permafrost in this region is very sensitive to the increasing warming rate. Significant degradation of permafrost in most sub-regions of the TP has occurred and continues to occur. The presence of permafrost and its changes alter or modify soil hydrothermal and biological processes, thereby affecting ecosystem service functions and water systems. In particular, the degradation of permafrost may affect the stability of infrastructure by reducing the substrate strength and increasing soil permeability, mass movement frequency, thermokarst activity and greenhouse gas fluxes. Existing maps of permafrost/frozen soil on the TP include the China Map of Snow, Ice, and Frozen Ground (1:4000000), the Tibetan Plateau Permafrost Map (1:3000000), the Circum-Arctic Permafrost and Ground-ice Conditions Map (1:10000000), the China Map of Geocryological Regionalization and Classification (1:10000000), the China Map of Glaciers, Frozen Ground and Deserts (1:4000000), and two recently produced permafrost maps that are both derived from a temperature at the top of permafrost (TTOP) model. These maps indicate different levels of understanding of the permafrost distribution in different periods, and both contribute to the improvement of permafrost mapping on the TP. However, from the perspective of current knowledge and data accumulation, these existing permafrost maps have two weaknesses. First, the classification systems used in these maps are based on the areal continuity of permafrost, which is defined by the areal fraction of permafrost, except that the map of Zou et al. (2017) provides only the permafrost extent. This was mainly influenced by the system used in both the former Soviet Union and North America, where high-latitude permafrost zones predominate. However, permafrost at high elevations differs substantially from permafrost at high latitudes. There is an obvious vertical zonation in the distribution of high-elevation permafrost. The vertical projection of so-called "continuous permafrost" on a horizontal plane is usually not continuous but isolated. Therefore, the continuity-based system is not suitable for describing high-elevation permafrost. In addition, continuity is a relative term and depends on the map scale. This ambiguous definition of continuity and differences in mapping scale may lead to confusion and inconsistency in the mapped distribution of permafrost. Moreover, traditional permafrost mapping is limited by data scarcity. Global and regional permafrost mapping traditionally relies on in situ air temperature measurement data, but meteorological stations are sparse and unevenly distributed on the TP, with compromised representativeness. Only a few stations are distributed in the permafrost regions. The scarcity of such data is an obstacle for high-resolution permafrost mapping.
research objective: This paper aims to develop a new, general and high-resolution permafrost map over the TP based on the ground thermal stability classification system, as proposed by Cheng (1984), by integrating remotely sensed predictor variables, reanalysis data, and ground-measured MAGT using statistical learning technology.
challenges: It is currently challenging to capture its distribution characteristics at the 1 km scale. However, due to the high cost and challenge of ground temperature measurements at high elevations, performing finely spaced traditional MAGT measurements is very difficult.
methods: This study produces a new permafrost stability distribution map for the 2010s (2005–2015) derived from the predicted mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at a depth of zero annual amplitude (10–25 m) by integrating remotely sensed freezing degree-days and thawing degree-days, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, high-accuracy soil moisture data, and in situ MAGT measurements from 237 boreholes on the TP by using an ensemble learning method that employs a support vector regression model based on distance-blocked resampled training data with 200 repetitions.
dataset: The MAGT ground measurements at 237 boreholes widely distributed over the TP were integrated mainly from the permafrost monitoring network in China, existing literature, and some unpublished data. The depths of the MAGT observations are generally greater than 10 m. The elevations of these boreholes range from 3000 to 5300 m, and most of these measurements were made from 2005 to 2015. The high-quality soil moisture dataset used in this study was obtained from the Climatic Data Center, National Meteorological Information Center, China Meteorological Administration (CMA).
findings: Validation of the new permafrost map indicates that it is probably the most accurate of all currently available maps. This map shows that the total area of permafrost on the TP, excluding glaciers and lakes, is approximately 115.02 (105.47–129.59)×10^4 km^2. The areas corresponding to the very stable, stable, semi-stable, transitional, and unstable types are 0.86×10^4, 9.62×10^4, 38.45×10^4, 42.29×10^4, and 23.80×10^4 km^2, respectively. This new map is of fundamental importance for engineering planning and design, ecosystem management, and evaluation of the permafrost change in the future on the TP as a baseline.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure the mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to measure the MAGT on the Tibetan Plateau involves integrating in situ measurements from 237 boreholes distributed across the region. These measurements, which were generally taken at depths greater than 10 m, were supplemented by predictor variables such as remotely sensed freezing and thawing degree-days, snow cover days, and more.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when mapping permafrost distribution at a 1 km resolution on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge when mapping permafrost distribution at a 1 km resolution on the Tibetan Plateau is the high cost and difficulty of performing finely spaced traditional MAGT measurements at high elevations due to the rugged and remote terrain.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to study permafrost stability on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to study permafrost stability on the Tibetan Plateau includes ground measurements of MAGT from 237 boreholes, obtained from the permafrost monitoring network in China, existing literature, and some unpublished data. This dataset was complemented by high-quality soil moisture data from the Climatic Data Center, National Meteorological Information Center, China Meteorological Administration (CMA).

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for permafrost mapping on the Tibetan Plateau using remotely sensed data compare to those using in situ MAGT measurements from boreholes?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for permafrost mapping on the Tibetan Plateau that use remotely sensed data involve integrating freezing degree-days, thawing degree-days, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, and high-accuracy soil moisture data. In contrast, in situ MAGT measurements are collected from 237 boreholes distributed across the plateau, with measurements taken at depths generally greater than 10 meters. While remotely sensed data provide broader spatial coverage and integrate various environmental parameters, in situ measurements offer precise ground-truth data at specific locations.

Comparison.Question: What differences exist between the support vector regression model used for permafrost mapping and traditional mapping methods based on areal continuity?
Comparison.Answer: The support vector regression model used for permafrost mapping integrates remotely sensed data and reanalysis data with in situ measurements to produce a high-resolution permafrost stability distribution map, focusing on the mean annual ground temperature. Traditional mapping methods based on areal continuity primarily classify permafrost by its spatial extent and continuity, which may not capture high-elevation permafrost's vertical zonation. The support vector regression model offers a statistical learning approach that can handle sparse data and provide finer spatial resolution.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges exist in collecting high-resolution ground temperature data on the Tibetan Plateau, and how might these challenges impact data accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: Collecting high-resolution ground temperature data on the Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to the high cost and logistical difficulties of conducting measurements at high elevations. Sparse and unevenly distributed meteorological stations further complicate data collection efforts, potentially compromising the representativeness and accuracy of in situ measurements. This scarcity of data poses an obstacle to achieving high-resolution permafrost mapping and underscores the importance of integrating additional data sources, such as remotely sensed data, to enhance map accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of capturing permafrost distribution characteristics at a 1 km scale on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges arise primarily due to the high cost and difficulty of ground temperature measurements at high elevations, making it hard to perform finely spaced traditional mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a scarcity of high-resolution data for permafrost mapping on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity is due to the limited number and uneven distribution of meteorological stations on the Tibetan Plateau, especially in permafrost regions, which compromises the representativeness of in situ air temperature measurements traditionally used for global and regional permafrost mapping.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the inconsistency in the mapped distribution of permafrost on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inconsistency arises from the use of classification systems based on areal continuity, which is unsuitable for high-elevation permafrost that displays obvious vertical zonation. Additionally, differences in mapping scale and the ambiguous definition of continuity contribute to this inconsistency.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating remotely sensed predictor variables with ground-measured MAGT in creating a permafrost map for the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remotely sensed predictor variables with ground-measured MAGT can lead to the development of a high-resolution permafrost map that captures the distribution characteristics at a 1 km scale. This approach can overcome the challenges of data scarcity from sparse meteorological stations, offering a more accurate representation of permafrost distribution and thermal stability, which is crucial for engineering planning, ecosystem management, and evaluating future permafrost changes on the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the consequences of using a support vector regression model on the accuracy of permafrost stability maps?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a support vector regression model can enhance the accuracy of permafrost stability maps by effectively integrating diverse datasets, such as remotely sensed data and in situ measurements. This method can produce a permafrost map with reduced root mean square error and minimal bias, thereby providing a reliable baseline for assessing permafrost distribution and stability on the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a high-resolution permafrost map over the Tibetan Plateau using statistical learning technology?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to create a new, general, and high-resolution permafrost map based on the ground thermal stability classification system, integrating remotely sensed predictor variables, reanalysis data, and ground-measured mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) using statistical learning to improve the understanding and mapping of permafrost distribution.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of integrating remotely sensed data and in situ measurements for permafrost mapping in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating remotely sensed data and in situ measurements allows for a more accurate and comprehensive permafrost map, overcoming challenges posed by sparse meteorological stations and the high costs of traditional ground temperature measurements in high-elevation areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to classify the thermal stability of permafrost in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Classifying the thermal stability of permafrost is crucial for understanding its distribution and potential changes, which have significant implications for engineering planning, ecosystem management, and evaluating future permafrost changes as a baseline.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in integrating remote sensing data with in situ measurements to create a high-resolution permafrost distribution map?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves integrating remotely sensed freezing and thawing degree-days, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, and high-accuracy soil moisture data with in situ mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) measurements from 237 boreholes. This integration is achieved using an ensemble learning method that employs a support vector regression model with distance-blocked resampled training data executed in 200 repetitions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are involved in capturing the distribution characteristics of permafrost at a 1 km scale on the Tibetan Plateau, and how are these challenges addressed procedurally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The challenges include the high cost and difficulty of ground temperature measurements at high elevations, which make finely spaced traditional MAGT measurements challenging. These challenges are addressed by integrating ground measurements with remote sensing and reanalysis data, and employing statistical learning techniques to create a high-resolution permafrost map, ensuring comprehensive coverage despite the sparse distribution of meteorological stations.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in remote sensing technology facilitate the collection of predictor variables necessary for creating high-resolution permafrost maps?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in remote sensing technology allow for the collection of predictor variables such as freezing degree-days, thawing degree-days, snow cover days, and leaf area index. These variables are essential for developing high-resolution permafrost maps and are integrated with ground measurements using statistical models to enhance mapping accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors make it challenging to perform high-resolution ground temperature measurements across the Tibetan Plateau, and how are these challenges addressed in data collection methods?
Enablement.Answer: The high cost and difficulty of performing finely spaced traditional MAGT measurements at high elevations make it challenging. These challenges are addressed by integrating in situ MAGT measurements from boreholes with remotely sensed data and reanalysis data, using statistical learning methods to predict MAGT and map permafrost stability.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might researchers face when collecting ground temperature data at high elevations, and how can these be mitigated?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the high cost and challenge of ground temperature measurements at high elevations, performing finely spaced traditional MAGT measurements is very difficult. This challenge can be mitigated by using an ensemble learning method with a support vector regression model that leverages remotely sensed data and reanalysis datasets to predict ground temperature characteristics without relying solely on ground-based measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to consider the vertical zonation of high-elevation permafrost when developing permafrost maps?
Expectation.Answer: High-elevation permafrost differs substantially from high-latitude permafrost due to its vertical zonation, where the vertical projection of so-called 'continuous permafrost' is usually not continuous but isolated. This unique characteristic requires a mapping approach that does not rely on continuity-based systems, which are more suitable for high-latitude permafrost, to accurately describe the distribution of high-elevation permafrost.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using support vector regression models in integrating various datasets for mapping permafrost distribution on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of support vector regression models is effective in integrating datasets such as remotely sensed freezing and thawing indices, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, high-accuracy soil moisture, and in situ ground temperature measurements. This approach allows for the creation of a high-resolution permafrost map, overcoming challenges of data scarcity and improving accuracy, as validated by the low root mean square error and bias in the resultant map.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in collecting high-resolution ground temperature data at high elevations, and how might these challenges impact the accuracy of permafrost mapping?
Judgmental.Answer: Collecting high-resolution ground temperature data at high elevations is challenging due to the high cost and difficulty of performing finely spaced measurements. The sparse and uneven distribution of meteorological stations on the Tibetan Plateau compromises data representativeness, which can impact the accuracy of permafrost mapping. However, integrating remotely sensed data and reanalysis data can help mitigate these challenges and improve map accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the integration of additional environmental variables enhance the accuracy and applicability of permafrost maps for engineering and ecological management on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating additional environmental variables such as more detailed soil properties, vegetation cover dynamics, or climate change projections could enhance the accuracy and applicability of permafrost maps. This would provide a more comprehensive understanding of permafrost dynamics and their implications for engineering planning, ecological management, and future permafrost change assessments on the Tibetan Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how to effectively integrate remote sensing data with ground-measured temperatures for mapping permafrost.
Assertion.Answer: The integration involves using a support vector regression model that combines ground-measured mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) data from 237 boreholes with remotely sensed variables such as freezing degree-days, thawing degree-days, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, and high-accuracy soil moisture data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges in obtaining high-resolution permafrost maps at a 1 km scale over the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: The key challenge is the high cost and difficulty of conducting finely spaced ground temperature measurements at high elevations, which makes it difficult to capture detailed distribution characteristics. Additionally, there is a scarcity of meteorological stations in permafrost regions, leading to limited in situ data for high-resolution mapping.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of what datasets are crucial for studying permafrost stability on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Crucial datasets include ground measurements of mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at borehole sites distributed over the plateau, remotely sensed data on freezing and thawing degree-days, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, and high-quality soil moisture data from the Climatic Data Center of China's National Meteorological Information Center.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for permafrost mapping in the Tibetan Plateau, highlighting the integration of different data sources and methodologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Permafrost mapping in the Tibetan Plateau involved integrating ground thermal stability classification with remotely sensed data, reanalysis data, and ground-measured mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) using statistical learning technology. The data collection incorporated remotely sensed freezing and thawing indices, snow cover days, leaf area index, soil bulk density, high-quality soil moisture data, and ground measurements from 237 boreholes. These measurements were generally taken at depths greater than 10 m and at elevations ranging from 3000 to 5300 m.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methodologies for expanding or refining datasets related to permafrost mapping on the Tibetan Plateau, considering the current limitations in data scarcity and distribution.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential methodologies for expanding or refining datasets could include increasing the density and distribution of borehole measurements across the plateau, integrating more comprehensive remote sensing data with refined temporal and spatial resolutions, and leveraging machine learning models to predict permafrost characteristics in areas lacking in situ data. Additionally, collaboration with international permafrost monitoring networks could enhance data availability and improve mapping accuracy.
